---
title: "package.json"
---

## High-level description
This `package.json` file defines the configuration and metadata for the `util-deprecate` npm package. The package provides a browser-compatible version of Node.js's `util.deprecate()` function, allowing developers to mark functions as deprecated in both Node.js and browser environments.

## Symbols

### Package Metadata
#### Description
The package metadata includes essential information about the `util-deprecate` package, such as its name, version, description, and entry points for different environments.

#### Internal Logic
- The package name is "util-deprecate"
- The current version is "1.0.2"
- The main entry point for Node.js is "node.js"
- The browser entry point is "browser.js"

### Scripts
#### Description
Defines the available npm scripts for the package.

#### Internal Logic
- Only a placeholder test script is defined, which throws an error indicating no tests are specified

### Repository
#### Description
Specifies the type and URL of the source code repository.

#### Internal Logic
- The repository type is "git"
- The repository URL is "git://github.com/TooTallNate/util-deprecate.git"

### Keywords
#### Description
Lists relevant keywords for the package to improve discoverability.

#### Internal Logic
Keywords include: "util", "deprecate", "browserify", "browser", "node"

### Author
#### Description
Provides information about the package author.

#### Internal Logic
The author is Nathan Rajlich, with email and website information provided

### License
#### Description
Specifies the license under which the package is distributed.

#### Internal Logic

### Bugs
#### Description
Provides a URL for reporting issues related to the package.

#### Internal Logic

### Homepage
#### Description
Specifies the official homepage or documentation site for the package.

#### Internal Logic
The homepage is set to "https://github.com/TooTallNate/util-deprecate"

## Dependencies
This package.json file does not list any dependencies, indicating that the `util-deprecate` package does not rely on any external npm packages.
